) Purpose and Scope of Chapter
Generally, Chapter

allows for the rec- ognition in the United States of foreign insolvency proceedings, access to the domestic judicial proceedings by foreign representatives, and other speciﬁc relief upon recognition. Chapter
was added to the Bankruptcy Code in
to incorporate the Model Law on Cross - Border Insolvency to provide mecha- nisms to address cross-border Insolvency matters. Objectives of Chapter
include promoting cooperation between the United States’ bankruptcy system
5.9 Bankruptcy and Other Insolvencies

and foreign authorities involved in cross-border insolvency cases, providing greater legal certainty for trade and investment, and creating fair and administration of cross-border insolvencies. Chapter 15 applies where:
administration of cross-border insolvencies. Chapter

applies where: a. A foreign court or a foreign representative seeks assistance in the States in connection with a foreign proceeding; b. Assistance is requested in a foreign country in connection with a case under
USC; c. A foreign proceeding and a domestic bankruptcy for the same debtor are pending concurrently; or d. Parties of interest in a foreign country wish to commence or participate a case under
USC. (
) Chapter
Chapter

is divided into several subchapters (general provi- sions; access of foreign representatives and creditors to the court; of a foreign proceeding and relief; cooperation with foreign courts and foreign representatives; and concurrent proceedings) that provide a framework for operation between the United States and foreign countries as to insolvency cases. The proceedings commenced under Chapter
are termed “ancillary” cases. Other deﬁned terms (see
USC §
) unique for Chapter

are: a. “Debtor” - an entity subject to a foreign proceeding. b. “Foreign court” - a judicial or other authority competent to control or supervise a foreign proceeding. c. “Foreign main proceeding” - a foreign proceeding pending in the country where the debtor has the center of its main interests. d. “Foreign nonmain proceeding” - a foreign proceeding (other than a main proceeding) pending in a country where the debtor has an ment. e. “Recognition” - the entry of an order granting recognition of a foreign proceeding or foreign nonmain proceeding under Chapter
Note:
USC §
requires the court to take into account the international origins of the Chapter and to apply it consistently with other similar statutes adopted by foreign jurisdictions. (

) Petition for Recognition. To commence an ancillary case under Chapter a petition for recognition of the foreign proceeding is ﬁled by the foreign sentative. The Bankruptcy Code requires that certain documents accompany the petition for recognition, such as a certiﬁed copy of the decision ing the foreign proceeding and appointing the foreign representative; a certiﬁcate from the foreign court affirming the existence of such foreign pro- ceeding and the appointment of the foreign representative; or any other acceptable evidence proving the existence of the proceeding and The petition for recognition should also be accompanied by a statement fying all known foreign proceedings related to the debtor. All documents must be translated into English. Also, Bankruptcy Rule

) sets forth addi- tional documents that must be ﬁled with the petition for recognition. Note: All documents accompanying the petition for recognition should be by the Insolvency caseworkers for references to the Internal Revenue Service, including such references as the Commissioner of the Internal Revenue, the United States or the Department of the Treasury. It may be necessary to research the references to determine the extent of the ment of the Internal Revenue Service. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Chapter 15. Chapter 15 is divided into several subchapters (general provi- sions; access of foreign representatives and creditors to the court; of a foreign proceeding and relief; cooperation with foreign courts and foreign representatives; and concurrent proceedings) that provide a framework for operation between the United States and foreign countries as to insolvency cases. The proceedings commenced under Chapter 15 are termed “ancillary”

a. “Debtor” - an entity subject to a foreign proceeding. b. “Foreign court” - a judicial or other authority competent to control or supervise a foreign proceeding. c. “Foreign main proceeding” - a foreign proceeding pending in the country where the debtor has the center of its main interests. d. “Foreign nonmain proceeding” - a foreign proceeding (other than a main proceeding) pending in a country where the debtor has an ment. e. “Recognition” - the entry of an order granting recognition of a foreign proceeding or foreign nonmain proceeding under Chapter
) Petition for Recognition. To commence an ancillary case under Chapter

, a petition for recognition of the foreign proceeding is ﬁled by the foreign repre- sentative. The Bankruptcy Code requires that certain documents accompany the petition for recognition, such as a certiﬁed copy of the decision commenc- ing the foreign proceeding and appointing the foreign representative; a certiﬁcate from the foreign court affirming the existence of such foreign pro- ceeding and the appointment of the foreign representative; or any other acceptable evidence proving the existence of the proceeding and appointment. The petition for recognition should also be accompanied by a statement identi- fying all known foreign proceedings related to the debtor. All documents must be translated into English. Also, Bankruptcy Rule
) sets forth addi- tional documents that must be ﬁled with the petition for recognition.

All documents accompanying the petition for recognition should be reviewed by the Insolvency caseworkers for references to the Internal Revenue Service, including such references as the Commissioner of the Internal Revenue, the United States or the Department of the Treasury. It may be necessary to research the references to determine the extent of the involve
ment of the Internal Revenue Service.
Chapter 9 and Chapter 15 Bankruptcy Cases 5.9.7 page 3
) Notice of Hearing on Petition for Recognition. Bankruptcy Rule

) provides that the clerk, or some other person as the court may direct, notice of the recognition hearing to the debtor, all persons or bodies to administer foreign proceedings of the debtor, all entities against whom sional relief (discussed below) is sought, all parties to litigation pending in the United States in which the debtor is a party at the time of the ﬁling of the petition, and such other entities as the court may direct. Such notice must be mailed at least

days in advance of the hearing on the petition for recogni- tion of a foreign proceeding and such notice must state whether the petition seeks recognition as a foreign main proceeding or foreign nonmain proceed- ing. See Bankruptcy Rule
(q). Note: The Bankruptcy Rules provide how the foreign representative must serve process when a petition for recognition is ﬁled as to a foreign nonmain pro- ceeding. See Bankruptcy Rule
USC §
(c) describes the notice requirements as to foreign creditors. (
) Provisional Relief. Unlike voluntary cases ﬁled under title

, the automatic stay does not go into effect when a petition for recognition is ﬁled. There a gap period from the ﬁling of the petition for recognition until the court rules on the petition. Where relief is urgently needed to protect the assets of the debtor or the interests of creditors, the foreign representative may request visional relief. The court may grant the following types of provisional relief: • Staying execution against the debtor’s assets. • Permitting the foreign representative or other authorized person, to ad- minister the debtor’s assets located in the United States to protect and preserve value. This generally involves assets which are perishable, susceptible to devaluation, or may otherwise be in jeopardy. • Suspending the right to transfer, encumber or otherwise dispose of assets of the debtor. • Providing for discovery of the debtor’s assets and liabilities. • Granting any additional relief that would be available to a trustee (excluding
USC §§

(a)). Caution: Caseworkers should not assume that action can be taken against assets of the debtor because the automatic stay does not go into effect at the time the petition is ﬁled. They should determine if the court has granted

provides that the clerk, or some other person as the court may direct, notice of the recognition hearing to the debtor, all persons or bodies to administer foreign proceedings of the debtor, all entities against whom sional relief (discussed below) is sought, all parties to litigation pending in the United States in which the debtor is a party at the time of the ﬁling of the petition, and such other entities as the court may direct. Such notice must be mailed at least 21 days in advance of the hearing on the petition for recogni- tion of a foreign proceeding and such notice must state whether the petition seeks recognition as a foreign main proceeding or foreign nonmain proceed- ing. See Bankruptcy Rule 2002(q).
Provisional Relief. Unlike voluntary cases ﬁled under title

, the automatic stay does not go into effect when a petition for recognition is ﬁled. There exists a gap period from the ﬁling of the petition for recognition until the court rules on the petition. Where relief is urgently needed to protect the assets of the debtor or the interests of creditors, the foreign representative may request pro- visional relief. The court may grant the following types of provisional relief:

Provisional Relief. Unlike voluntary cases ﬁled under title 11, the automatic stay does not go into effect when a petition for recognition is ﬁled. There a gap period from the ﬁling of the petition for recognition until the court rules on the petition. Where relief is urgently needed to protect the assets of the debtor or the interests of creditors, the foreign representative may request pro- visional relief. The court may grant the following types of provisional relief:

Staying execution against the debtor’s assets. Permitting the foreign representative or other authorized person, to minister the debtor’s assets located in the United States to protect preserve value. This generally involves assets which are perishable, susceptible to devaluation, or may otherwise be in jeopardy. Suspending the right to transfer, encumber or otherwise dispose of assets of the debtor. Providing for discovery of the debtor’s assets and liabilities. Granting any additional relief that would be available to a trustee (excluding
USC §§

Caseworkers should not assume that action can be taken against assets of the debtor because the automatic stay does not go into effect at the time the petition is ﬁled. They should determine if the court has granted provisional relief to the foreign representative that would prohibit any action proposed by the Internal Revenue Service. If there is a question to whether the action has been prohibited by an order of provisional relief, Counsel should be consulted.

Caseworkers should not assume that action can be taken against assets of the debtor because the automatic stay does not go into effect at the time the petition is ﬁled. They should determine if the court has granted provisional relief to the foreign representative that would prohibit any action proposed by the Internal Revenue Service. If there is a question as to whether the action has been prohibited by an order of provisional relief, Counsel should be consulted.
Provisional relief terminates (unless extended by the Bankruptcy Court) when the petition for recognition is granted. (

) Effects of Recognition of a Foreign Main Proceeding. When the court enters an order recognizing a foreign main proceeding, certain relief is granted to the foreign representative automatically, including, among other relief: •
USC §§
(adequate protection) and
(automatic stay) apply to the debtor and the debtor’s property within the territorial jurisdiction of the United States. •
USC §§
(use, sale or lease of property),
(post-petition trans-

Effects of Recognition of a Foreign Main Proceeding. When the court enters an order recognizing a foreign main proceeding, certain relief is granted to the foreign representative automatically, including, among other relief:
USC §§
(adequate protection) and
(automatic stay) apply to the debtor and the debtor’s property within the territorial jurisdiction of the United States.
USC §§
(use, sale or lease of property),
(post-petition trans- actions) and
(post-petition effect of security interest) apply to a
5.9 Bankruptcy and Other Insolvencies

transfer of interest of the debtor that is within the territorial jurisdiction of the United States to the same extent as those sections would apply to property of the estate. The foreign representative may operate the debtor’s business and exercise the powers of a trustee under
USC §§
and
, unless the court orders otherwise.

The court may grant any additional appropriate relief requested by the foreign representative once the court recognizes the foreign proceeding (whether main or nonmain) within the parameters of 11 USC § 1521 including (among other relief):

A stay of the commencement or continuation of a proceeding the debtor’s assets, rights, obligations or liabilities to the extent not already stayed. A stay of execution against the debtor’s assets. A suspension of the right to transfer, encumber or otherwise dispose the debtor’s assets. Providing for discovery of the debtor’s assets and liabilities. Granting any additional relief that may be available to a trustee (excluding
USC §§
, and

(a)). Permitting the foreign representative or other authorized person to ad- minister the debtor’s assets located in the United States. Permitting the foreign representative to distribute all or part of the debtor’s assets located within the United States to the foreign tative or to another person, provided the court is satisﬁed that the interests of creditors in the United States are sufficiently protected.

) Coordination of a Case Under Title
and a Foreign Proceeding. If a foreign proceeding and a case under another chapter of title
are pending the same time regarding the same debtor, the Bankruptcy Court must seek cooperation and coordination with the foreign courts or representatives and may suspend or dismiss the title
case, if in the interest of the creditors the debtor. (
) Case Pending Under Another Chapter at the Time Petition for Recogni- tion is Filed. When there is a case under another chapter pending at the a Chapter

case is ﬁled, relief (including provisional relief) will be granted only if consistent with the relief granted in the case pending in the United States, and the effects of recognition of a foreign main proceeding (such as the automatic stay) do not apply. Generally a United States case trumps a foreign proceeding. (

) Case Commenced Under Another Chapter after Recognition or Petition for Recognition Filed. If a case is ﬁled under another bankruptcy chapter after a petition for recognition is ﬁled or after recognition is granted to the foreign representative, any relief granted in the Chapter
case must be modiﬁed or terminated if it is inconsistent with the case under another of the Bankruptcy Code. (

case should be aware that an in any other case ﬁled under the Bankruptcy Code and involving the may affect the actions that can be taken. It may be necessary to review docket sheets of both cases. If there is any question as to whether an can be taken, Counsel should be consulted. (

cases, Centralized Insolvency’s ment with Chapter

payments that are sent to the CIO in error rather than to the Field Insolvency office handling the case. Any reports generated by the Insolvency Interface must be forwarded to the Field Insolvency group assigned the case expedited procedures. (See IRM
, Time Sensitive Mail.) (

payments received at the CIO must be applied to the non plan screen. The CIO Payment Posting Unit must advise the Field Insolvency office assigned the case of the payment receipt, so the CIO payment can be applied to the proper tax liability. (

case, Field Insolvency add the case to AIS. The caseworker must review the Chapter

5.9 Bankruptcy and Other Insolvencies
If the petition for recognition and the related documents indicate that the foreign representative is requesting recogni

tion in order to sell assets of the debtor located in the United States, the debtor may owe income taxes to the United States as a consequence of the sale. If the caseworker has any questions as to whether a proposed sale will have tax consequences, the caseworker should contact Counsel.

such as a change from return ﬁling requirements or a request that the debtor’s liability under the Internal Revenue Code be limited. If none of criteria is met, the caseworker does not need to make a referral to Counsel and the case can be closed. If a referral is made, the case should remain open until Counsel indicates it can be closed. Notiﬁcation of Filings in a Chapter
Case. If Field Insolvency receives notice of the ﬁling of a motion or other document in a Chapter

case and initial case review has not previously been conducted, caseworkers should conduct an initial review of the case, including a review of the document received, and determine if a referral should be made to Counsel. If an initial case review was previously conducted and it was determined the referral criteria was not met, the caseworker should review the document received determine if it is now necessary to refer the case based on a change in tions. If the caseworker has questions about the document received, should be contacted for guidance. For cases previously referred, the should be forwarded to Counsel for association with the case. Referral to Counsel. Caseworkers should refer cases meeting the referral criteria as soon as possible after the initial case review, or after a determina- tion is made following receipt of notice that the referral criteria has been met. Caseworkers should include the following items in the referral package: • A draft of a proof of claim showing the outstanding tax liability to the United States, if any; Note: A claim is ﬁled in a Chapter

case only if the court orders it. • A copy of any proofs of claim ﬁled in a case ﬁled under any other chapter for the debtor. • A referral memo providing the name of the debtor, the complete TIN, any, the case number and the court where the Chapter
case was ﬁled, and the reason for the referral. If a case is open for the debtor

) Revenue Rule. Generally, the Service does not participate in foreign insol- vency proceedings because the majority of countries, including the U.S., Debt in a prohibit the enforcement of foreign tax claims in their courts. This prohibition When commonly referred to as the revenue rule. The revenue rule provides that country ever takes notice of the revenue laws of another. (

) Tax Treaties. Claims in foreign insolvency proceedings may be pursued through the mutual collection assistance request (MCAR) process provided under some U.S. Tax treaties. These tax treaties abrogate (or supersede) revenue rule with respect to the U.S. and the particular treaty partner. Currently, there are ﬁve countries with which the U.S. has tax treaties that provide for mutual collection assistance - Canada, Denmark, France, the erlands, and Sweden. The tax treaties between the U.S. and these permit the U.S. and the other country to collect, for each other, taxes that been ﬁnally determined (i.e., assessed and subject to immediate collection). (

) Filing Claims. When notiﬁed of an insolvency proceeding in a foreign Insolvency should refer the matter to Counsel to be coordinated with Branch Office of the Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure and Administration). In treaty countries, there are important considerations as to whether the should proceed with collection, such as the ability to defend the claim of the disclosure rules in IRC §
and the potential for subjecting the (as a whole) to a foreign court’s jurisdiction.

commonly referred to as the revenue rule. The revenue rule provides that no country ever takes notice of the revenue laws of another. (

) Tax Treaties. Claims in foreign insolvency proceedings may be pursued through the mutual collection assistance request (MCAR) process provided under some U.S. Tax treaties. These tax treaties abrogate (or supersede) the revenue rule with respect to the U.S. and the particular treaty partner. Currently, there are ﬁve countries with which the U.S. has tax treaties that provide for mutual collection assistance - Canada, Denmark, France, the erlands, and Sweden. The tax treaties between the U.S. and these countries permit the U.S. and the other country to collect, for each other, taxes that been ﬁnally determined (i.e., assessed and subject to immediate collection). (

) Filing Claims. When notiﬁed of an insolvency proceeding in a foreign country, Insolvency should refer the matter to Counsel to be coordinated with Branch Office of the Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure and Administration). In non- treaty countries, there are important considerations as to whether the Service should proceed with collection, such as the ability to defend the claim because of the disclosure rules in IRC §
and the potential for subjecting the U.S. (as a whole) to a foreign court’s jurisdiction.
